title: About Verraten und Verkauft
description:
This is an interactive map of The exhibition Final Sale: The End of Jewish Owned Businesses in Nazi Berlin, whixh is based on the findings of research carried out by staff and students at the Department of Modern German History of Berlin's Humboldt University. The conclusive findings of the research project, which investigated the fate of small and medium-sized businesses in Berlin 1930-45, was published in 2012. The exhibition was produced in cooperation with the historical society Aktives Museum Faschis-
mus und Widerstand in Berlin e.V., which has been devoted to creating historical exhibitions with a biographical focus since its inception in 1983.
Sixteen businesses were selected from the large number and wide variety of Jewish businesses in Berlin for the exhibition. Although they do not provide a comprehensive picture, they serve as examples for branches, fields of business and specific contexts which have previously not been the focus of historical interest. The intention is to add less widely known information to the cases already well documented in order to uncover new aspects of the history of Jewish commercial enterprise in Berlin during this period. The individual case histories are framed by photos of Berlin businesses which were targeted by boycott or willful destruction, visualizing the concrete threat that Jewish businesses faced. In this case, some well known photos were included of stores at unknown locations. Thanks to the
project's database, these could be accurately identified for the first time.

title: E. Braun & Co. Berlin.
description:
Founded by brothers Emanuel and Josef Braun in Vienna, E. Braun & Co. began as a bridal wear and accessories store. The company expanded to become a supplier to the Austrian imperial court, opening branches in Karlovy Vary and Prague. In 1914, they established their Berlin branch on Unter den Linden 75, which grew into a luxurious store offering formal wear, table linen, and home accessories.

Emanuel Braun, considered the inventor of the boutique concept, partnered with Siegfried Franz Oser-Braun to run the Berlin branch. The store flourished, with its premises renovated in 1926-1928 at a cost of 850,000 Reich marks.

However, Austria's annexation in 1938 dramatically changed the company's fortunes. Siegfried Franz Oser-Braun was arrested, and while in detention, was forced to sell the company to Georg Wiedemann. The Oser-Braun family fled, first to London, then Egypt, and finally to the USA in 1941.

After the war, the company was returned to its founders' heirs. Henry Myer (formerly Hans Friedrich Mayer-Braun) became director in 1962. The Berlin branch, destroyed during the war, was not rebuilt. In 1988, Gustavo Oser sold the rights to the company name.

title: A. Breslaur
description:
With the help of his many friends in the book trade and at great material cost, the internationally successful antiquarian bookseller Martin Breslauer - heart and soul of the Berlin Bibliophile Society and fervent German patriot - managed to emigrate and make a modest new start in Lon-don. But, in fall 1940, a German aerial bomb literally startled him to death. The heart of Berlin's Bibliophile Society
Martin Breslauer, born on December 16, 1871, studied German and Palaeography at Rostock University before completing
apprenticeships at some of Europe's most renowned bookstores, including Menozzi in Rome, Welter in Paris, Hachette in Lon- don and Joseph Baer in Frankfurt am Main. At the age of 26, he decided to set up his own business. On February 4, 1898, he and his former school friend Edmund Meyer founded the antiquarian and retail bookstore Antiquariats- und Sortiments- buchhandlung Breslauer &Meyer at Potsdamer Strasse 27b.

title: The Deutsche Theater: A Cultural Icon Seized
description:
Founded in 1883, the Deutsche Theater on Schumann Strasse became the epicenter of Berlin's theatrical world under the visionary leadership of Max Reinhardt. From 1906 to 1933, Reinhardt transformed this modest playhouse into a cultural powerhouse, pioneering innovative staging techniques and nurturing new dramatic talent.

At its peak, the DT was the crown jewel of Reinhardt's theatrical empire, which included 12 theaters and over 10,000 seats across Berlin. The theater's success allowed Reinhardt to experiment with grand productions, including the opening of the Grosse Schauspielhaus in 1919, which seated an astounding 3,200 spectators.

However, the Deutsche Theater's golden age came to an abrupt end in 1933 when the Nazis systematically ousted Reinhardt, a Jewish artist, from his position. This seizure represented more than just a business takeover; it was a calculated move by the Nazi regime to appropriate the theater's prestige and cultural significance for their own propaganda purposes.

Reinhardt's forced exile marked a tragic turning point, not only for the Deutsche Theater but for German culture as a whole. The theater, once a beacon of artistic innovation and freedom, became a tool in the hands of a repressive regime, its legacy of creativity and inclusivity temporarily erased from Berlin's cultural landscape.

Today, the Deutsche Theater stands as a poignant reminder of both the heights of artistic achievement and the depths of cultural persecution in 20th century Germany.

title: Ebro Upholstery: Innovation and Persecution in Berlin's Automotive Industry
description:
Ebro, an acronym for Erste Berliner Dampf-Rosshaarspinnerei, revolutionized the upholstery industry with its unique horsehair spinning technique. By 1924, it had evolved from a wholesale supplier to a stock corporation, with Richard's brother Ernst joining as a partner. The company's exceptional quality made it a crucial supplier to Germany's booming automobile industry.
Despite its economic significance and "German interests" designation, Ebro faced increasing pressure after 1933. Heinrich Hunke, a Nazi Party economic advisor, orchestrated efforts to force the Jewish shareholders to surrender their factory. The company's success paradoxically made it a target for "Aryanization.

title: Fröhlich & Pelz: A Tale of Resilience and Reinvention
description: Moritz Fröhlich's journey from a thriving Berlin-based glass and porcelain business to American exile embodies the tumultuous fate of many Jewish entrepreneurs during the Nazi era. Establishing himself in the 1920s, Fröhlich built a successful enterprise that prospered until 1936, adapting to economic challenges and expanding to serve major department stores. Forced to flee in 1939, the Fröhlichs endured a two-year wait in Cuba before reaching the United States. Despite initial struggles in America, including a brief stint making army hats and unsuccessful attempts at philately, Fröhlich's legacy lived on through his son Peter, who became a renowned historian. Peter Gay's autobiographical work, "My German Question: Growing Up in Berlin 1933-1939," stands as a poignant testament to his father's resilience and the family's enduring impact on cultural and intellectual life, even in exile.

title: Alfred Höxter: From Prosperity to Persecution in Berlin's Grain Trade
description: Alfred Höxter established his grain wholesale business in 1919, quickly becoming one of the best-known companies in the Berlin commodity market. Through astute trading and partnerships, Höxter built a thriving enterprise that weathered the 1931 banking crisis, allowing him and his family to live comfortably in an eight-room apartment on Pariser Strasse. However, the rise of Nazi power in 1933 brought far-reaching changes, subjecting Jewish businessmen like Höxter to verbal abuse, boycotts, and systematic exclusion from the market. Despite initial resilience, the company's fortunes declined sharply under increasing anti-Semitic pressures and restrictions. By 1936, faced with untenable conditions, the Höxter family made the difficult decision to emigrate, closing a chapter on a once-prosperous business that fell victim to the Nazis' ruthless economic policies targeting Jewish enterprises.

title: Jacobowitz & Co.: A Century-Old Legacy Shattered by Nazi Persecution
description: Founded in the 19th century by Josef Jacobowitz, this family-run egg wholesale and retail business thrived for generations in Berlin's Bergmann Strasse. Under Albert Schlesinger's leadership from 1918, the company prospered, expanding its operations and becoming a cornerstone of Berlin's egg trade. However, the rise of Nazi power in 1933 brought devastating changes. Despite its long-standing reputation and economic importance, Jacobowitz & Co. fell victim to the regime's "blood and soil" ideology. By 1935, the business faced forced closure amidst a wider campaign to eliminate Jewish traders from the egg market. The family's desperate attempts to emigrate followed, with some members escaping to England and the United States. Tragically, Bertha Schlesinger perished in Theresienstadt in 1942. This once-thriving enterprise, valued at 75,000 Reichsmarks in the 1920s, was obliterated by arbitrary regulations, leaving behind only memories of a bustling family business that had served Berlin for nearly a century.

title: Jonass & Co.: From Retail Giant to Nazi Appropriation
description: Jonass & Co., a prominent Berlin department store founded by Hermann Golluber in the early 20th century, exemplified the rise and fall of Jewish-owned businesses under Nazi rule. Located near Alexanderplatz, it offered credit vouchers and catered to budget-conscious shoppers, growing from a mail-order business to a retail empire. The store's innovative design, complete with rooftop restaurant and garden, made it a local landmark. However, its success attracted Nazi attention, leading to its early appropriation even before 1933. By 1930, the store became a focal point for Nazi rallies, with its Jewish heritage erased. The company's 1933 report revealed a façade of normalcy, but behind the scenes, SA intimidation and boycotts devastated profits. In a final blow, Golluber was forced from the board in 1935, and the store was "Aryanized." This transformation from a thriving Jewish-owned business to a propaganda hub for the Nazi regime starkly illustrates the systematic economic persecution of Jews in Nazi Germany.

title: Karl Kutschera's Café Wien and Zigeunerkeller: From Popular Haunt to Nazi Target
description: Karl Kutschera's Café Wien and Zigeunerkeller, once vibrant fixtures on Berlin's Kurfürstendamm, embodied both the cultural richness of interwar Berlin and the tragic fate of Jewish-owned businesses under Nazi rule. Hungarian-born Kutschera transformed these establishments into popular international meeting spots, only to see them become targets of escalating anti-Semitic attacks. From the violent "Kurfürstendamm riots" of 1935 to the slanderous campaign by Der Stürmer in 1936, Kutschera's businesses faced relentless pressure. Despite initial resilience, he was eventually forced to lease to non-Jewish shareholders, with the Zigeunerkeller infamously declaring "Jews not welcome." The Kutschera family's subsequent deportation to Theresienstadt in 1943, resulting in the loss of two children in Auschwitz, reflected the broader tragedy of the Holocaust. Yet, in a testament to remarkable resilience, Karl and Josephine Kutschera survived, returned to Berlin post-war, and revived Café Wien. Kutschera's journey from successful entrepreneur to Nazi target, and his post-war resurgence, encapsulates the complex narrative of Jewish business owners in Nazi Germany and the enduring spirit of survival.

title: Private Kunst- und Kunstgewerbeschule Reimann
description:
Albert and Clara Reimann's Schule Reimann, founded in 1902 in Berlin-Schöneberg, emerged as a leading private art college inspired by the Bauhaus and Werkbund schools. Known for its innovative departments in fashion illustration, costume and textile design, and window design, the college flourished in the 1920s and early 1930s. At its peak, it enrolled 500-750 students, many from abroad, and boasted a profit margin of 30,000 Reich marks.

The college's fortunes changed dramatically after 1933. Despite initial attempts to adapt to Nazi rule, including hosting an exhibition supporting the National Socialist People's Welfare Organization, the Reimanns faced increasing pressure. The Reich Culture Chamber Law of 1933 led to Nazi control of the college, with SA members occupying the grounds and harassing students and tutors.

In 1935, the Reimanns were forced to sell the college to Hugo Häring, a non-Jewish principal. Although former Bauhaus artists continued teaching, the college faced severe criticism from Nazi authorities. The Reich Economic Ministry pushed for closure, citing the college's "Jewish influence." Despite Häring's efforts to prove the college's profitability and "Aryanization," financial difficulties mounted.

title: Ruilos Knoblauch-Verwertungs-G.m.b.H.
description: Founded in 1921 as a publicly traded company specializing in chemical products for medicinal and home hygiene purposes, Ruilos G.m.b.H. became a notable presence in Berlin's industrial landscape under the leadership of Dr. Georg Eppenstein. The company's growth was evident in its move to Goldschmieden and the establishment of a Berlin branch, reflecting its expanding influence in the chemical sector.

title: Kostümhaus Theaterkunst Hermann J. Kaufmann
description:
Founded in 1907 by Hermann J. Kaufmann, Theaterkunst became a world-renowned supplier of theatrical décor and costumes. At its peak, it boasted 360 employees across 1,500 square meters of workshops in Berlin. Kaufmann's innovative approach included strong advertising and high-profile commissions, like outfitting the 1926 film "Ben Hur."

The Nazi era brought dramatic changes. In 1933, Kaufmann faced pressure to surrender his business. Hermann Staltberg, an NSDAP member and SA leader, founded a rival company positioning itself as the "first purely Christian company" in the industry. By 1936, Kaufmann was forced to sell. The Swedish matchstick corporation STAB and businessman Adolph Nau took over, merging Kaufmann's business with Staltberg's under the Theaterkunst name.

Despite this upheaval, the company continued operations, supplying costumes for entertainment, propaganda, and even wartime purposes. Kaufmann, exiled to Brussels, died there in 1942. Today, Theaterkunst GmbH still exists, with its main office in Berlin and branches in other German cities, a complex legacy of both artistic achievement and historical persecution.

title: Egg Brothers: Eduard und Max Moses Wassermann
description:
Eduard and Max Wassermann, Jewish grocery traders in Berlin's northern suburb, exemplified different strategies to resist Nazi oppression in the 1930s. Eduard, born in 1883 in Tarnow, Poland, became a poultry trader in Berlin, expanding his business to include imported meat. Max, born in 1895, joined his brother in Berlin in 1912, establishing a successful egg wholesale business.

Despite their economic success and diverse defense strategies - one brother acting as a silent partner while the other managed the business - both ultimately faced the same tragic fate. They were among 534 Jewish men and youths with Polish passports arrested in Berlin and deported to Sachsenhausen concentration camp on September 13, 1939.

The brothers died in Sachsenhausen in 1940, allegedly of appendicitis. In reality, Eduard, who was diabetic, had both legs amputated there. Max, crushed by his brother's death, died less than a month later. Their story illustrates how even the most resourceful attempts to resist Nazi persecution often ended in deportation and murder.

title: The Weinberger Butter Brothers:
description:
The Gebrüder Weinberger butter business, Berlin's largest, grew from a grocery store established by Helene Weinberger in 1889. Hermann Weinberger married into the business, founding a wholesale grocery with his brothers Adolf, Israel, and Salomon. By the mid-1920s, they became Berlin's main butter suppliers, manufacturing their own butter, lard, and fat. They supplied about 8,000 small dairy goods stores and ran their own chain under the name Otto Thürmann.

Despite initial success weathering economic crises with help from Unilever, the company faced increasing Nazi persecution from 1933. The situation became critical when Unilever withdrew support in August 1935. The Nazi newspaper Der Angriff launched a campaign against the company, triggering boycotts and reducing available supplies.

Under extreme pressure, about two-thirds of the firm's employees left. The German Labor Front offered the company's supply quota to non-Jewish competitors, further strangling the business. By December 1935, the company was reduced to a "vegetative existence."

The brothers attempted various strategies to save the business, including partnering with individuals holding Polish nationality. However, these efforts ultimately proved futile against the relentless tide of Nazi persecution targeting Jewish-owned businesses.

title: Atelier Yva - Photographie
description:
Else Ernestine Neuländer, known professionally as Yva, rose to prominence as a fashion and commercial photographer in 1920s Berlin. Despite increasing oppression of Jews, she maintained her studio until 1938. Yva's innovative work included photo-stories for magazines and collaborations with fashion publications.

In 1934, Yva married Alfred Hermann Simon, who managed the studio's finances. They lived and worked at Schlüterstrasse 45, employing several staff including Elizabeth Röttgers, who became Yva's close friend. Yva was known for her professionalism and charm, training notable photographers like Helmut Newton.

As persecution intensified, Yva's non-Jewish clients and employees distanced themselves. In late 1938, Charlotte Weidler took over the studio briefly before it closed due to anti-Jewish laws. The Simons faced increasing isolation and moved to smaller apartments, considering emigration.

Tragically, in June 1942, the couple was arrested by the Gestapo and deported to Sobibór extermination camp. Their fate exemplifies the devastating impact of Nazi persecution on Jewish professionals and artists. Yva's legacy lives on through her groundbreaking work in fashion and commercial photography during the Weimar era.

title: Jüdische Liberale Zeitung offices
description: An important Jewish newspaper that provided liberal perspectives on Jewish issues and German politics

title: Haus Minkowski
description: Home of the famous mathematician Hermann Minkowski representing the private residences of notable Jewish figures

title: Phoenix AG
description: A major rubber company co-founded by Jewish entrepreneurs that became a significant industrial player

title: Akademie für die Wissenschaft des Judentums
description: An important center for Jewish scholarly research promoting the scientific study of Judaism

title: Fasanenstrasse Synagogue
description: Once the largest synagogue in Berlin serving the liberal Jewish community

title: Knoblauch House Synagogue
description: A private synagogue in the home of the wealthy Knoblauch family symbolizing the integration of Jews into high society

title: Artushof
description: A famous Jewish-owned restaurant and meeting place for intellectuals and artists

title: Kaufhaus Nathan Israel
description: One of the largest department stores in Berlin known for its wide range of goods

title: Kaufhaus Tietz
description: A major Jewish-owned department store chain that revolutionized retail in Germany

title: Café Dobrin
description: A famous Jewish-owned café known as a meeting place for artists and intellectuals

title: Ullstein Publishing House
description: A major Jewish-owned publishing house that was a cornerstone of German media and culture

title: Hochschule für die Wissenschaft des Judentums
description: A higher education institution for Jewish studies that trained many prominent rabbis and scholars

title: Home of Albert Einstein
description: Albert Einstein developed his General Theory of Relativity while living in Berlin where he was a prominent figure in the scientific community until forced to flee Nazi persecution.

title: Home of Max Liebermann
description: Max Liebermann a leading German impressionist painter lived and worked in Berlin for over 50 years serving as President of the Prussian Academy of Arts until ousted by the Nazis.

title: Home of Kurt Tucholsky
description: Kurt Tucholsky born in Berlin became one of the most important journalists and satirists of the Weimar Republic known for his sharp political commentary.

title: Home of Walter Benjamin
description: Walter Benjamin born and raised in Berlin became a critical theorist and philosopher writing many of his important works while living in the city.

title: Home of Rosa Luxemburg
description: Rosa Luxemburg a revolutionary socialist was a key figure in Berlin's political landscape co-founding the Spartacus League before her assassination in the city.

title: Home of Max Reinhardt
description: Max Reinhardt revolutionized German theater while in Berlin directing at and later owning the Deutsches Theater transforming it into a cultural landmark.

title: Home of Else Lasker-Schüler
description: Else Lasker-Schüler a prominent expressionist poet and artist was deeply connected to Berlin's bohemian scene often writing about the city in her work.

title: Max Brod
description: Max Brod though primarily associated with Prague briefly lived in Berlin before his final emigration connecting with the city's literary circles.

title: Home of Gershom Scholem
description: Gershom Scholem born in Berlin began his groundbreaking studies in Jewish mysticism here before emigrating to Jerusalem shaping modern Kabbalah scholarship.

title: Home of Stefan Heym
description: Stefan Heym born in Berlin began his writing career here before fleeing Nazi persecution later returning to become a significant voice in East German literature.

title: Home of Hermann Cohen
description: Hermann Cohen an influential Neo-Kantian philosopher taught at the Lehranstalt für die Wissenschaft des Judentums in Berlin shaping Jewish philosophical thought.

title: Home of Ernst Kantorowicz
description: Ernst Kantorowicz a medieval historian taught at the University of Frankfurt but lived in Berlin during a crucial period of his academic career.

title: Home of Theodor Wolff
description: Theodor Wolff editor-in-chief of the influential Berliner Tageblatt was a central figure in Berlin's journalism and a vocal critic of the rising Nazi party.

title: Home of Lesser Ury
description: Lesser Ury known for his impressionist paintings of Berlin street scenes captured the essence of the city's urban life in the early 20th century.

title: Home of Lion Feuchtwanger
description: Lion Feuchtwanger while in Berlin became a successful novelist and playwright using the city as a backdrop for some of his works before fleeing Nazi persecution.

title: Home of Ernst Lubitsch
description: Ernst Lubitsch born in Berlin began his film career here as an actor and director before moving to Hollywood and becoming a renowned filmmaker.

title: Home of Kurt Weill
description: Kurt Weill while living in Berlin collaborated with Bertolt Brecht on groundbreaking works like "The Threepenny Opera" revolutionizing musical theater.

title: Home of Nelly Sachs
description: Nelly Sachs born and raised in Berlin began her literary career here before fleeing to Sweden later winning the Nobel Prize for her poetic works dealing with Jewish suffering.

title: Home of Walter Rathenau
description: Walter Rathenau industrialist and politician served as Foreign Minister of Germany while living in Berlin assassinated by right-wing extremists in the city.

title: Home of Regina Jonas
description: Regina Jonas the first woman to be ordained as a rabbi lived and worked in Berlin serving the city's Jewish community until her deportation to Theresienstadt.

title: Home of Arnold Zweig
description: Arnold Zweig while in Berlin became a prominent pacifist and socialist writer using the city as a setting for some of his novels before exile.

title: Home of Gertrud Kolmar
description: Gertrud Kolmar a poet born in Berlin worked as a teacher in the city while writing her work largely unpublished until after her death in Auschwitz.

title: Home of Leo Baeck
description: Leo Baeck a rabbi and scholar led Berlin's Jewish community through the Nazi era teaching and writing until his deportation to Theresienstadt.

title: Ernst Toller
description: Ernst Toller a revolutionary playwright and political activist was a key figure in Berlin's expressionist theater scene and left-wing politics.

title: Alfred Döblin
description: Alfred Döblin while working as a doctor in Berlin wrote his famous novel "Berlin Alexanderplatz" capturing the essence of 1920s working-class Berlin.
